article.title: Phenomenological constraints on $A_N$ in $p^↑p→π X$ from Lorentz invariance relations

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows calculations of the contribution to A<sub>N</sub> from Equation (16) compared to experimental data from BRAHMS and STAR collaborations. What is the general trend of A<sub>N</sub> as a function of x<sub>F</sub> that is observed in both the calculations and the data?
choices: A<sub>N</sub> remains relatively flat as x<sub>F</sub> increases.
A<sub>N</sub>  increases steadily as x<sub>F</sub> increases.
A<sub>N</sub> decreases steadily as x<sub>F</sub> increases.
A<sub>N</sub> shows a sharp peak at a specific value of x<sub>F</sub>.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the STAR Collaboration data on A<sub>N</sub> for π<sup>0</sup> as a function of x<sub>F</sub>. What is the dominant source of theoretical uncertainty for large values of x<sub>F</sub>?
choices: Uncertainty in the Collins fragmentation function, H<sub>1</sub><sup>⟂(1)</sup>(z).
Uncertainty in the transversity PDF, h<sub>1</sub>(x).
Uncertainty in the Qiu-Sterman function, F<sub>FT</sub>(x,x).
Uncertainty in the unpolarized PDFs, f<sub>1</sub>(x).

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares calculations to STAR data for A<sub>N</sub> as a function of  p<sub>hT</sub>. What is the main feature observed in both the calculation and the data?
choices: A strong dependence of A<sub>N</sub> on p<sub>hT</sub>.
A weak dependence of A<sub>N</sub> on p<sub>hT</sub>.
A clear peak in A<sub>N</sub> at a specific value of p<sub>hT</sub>.
A sign change in A<sub>N</sub> as p<sub>hT</sub> increases.

multiple_choice_question.text: This equation represents a Lorentz Invariance Relation (LIR) for twist-3 fragmentation functions. What is the significance of this relation in the context of the paper?
choices: It connects the three twist-3 fragmentation functions, allowing the elimination of one unknown function.
It relates the fragmentation functions to the Qiu-Sterman function, simplifying the calculation.
It introduces a new dynamical function, Ĥ<sup>FU</sup>(z,z<sub>1</sub>), which is crucial for describing A<sub>N</sub>.
It demonstrates that the kinematical twist-3 function, H<sub>1</sub><sup>⟂(1)</sup>(z), is the dominant contribution to A<sub>N</sub>.
